p: Cholera, caused by the bacterium Vibrio cholerae, is reemerging in Africa as a result of limited access to drinking water and conflicts. Overpopulation, poverty, lack of hygiene, poor sanitation facilities, contamination of food and lack of safe water are the main risk factors for cholera [30], [31]. All these elements are also among the consequences of war and civil strife. In 2006, cholera was reported in 33 African countries; 88% of reports came from conflict-affected countries [31]. Cholera epidemics occur almost every year in Africa ( Table 1). The most severe outbreak of cholera was observed in Zimbabwe, with 98 585 reported cases including more than 4000 deaths from 2008 to 2009 [32], [33].
